text: examined and testified as follows:
-  -  - EXAMINATION

Good morning, Mr. Orner.  My name is Mike Gallagher.  I'm an attorney.  I represent Carla Brietman with respect to a motor vehicle accident that occurred on May 24th, 2018, in Haverford, Pennsylvania, at or near the intersection of Bon Air Avenue and Eagle Road.  Does that date and location sound familiar to you?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: It's not Eagle, but -- that's actually my house, the corner of Bon Air and Grand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So is it -- would it be --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Grand Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's on Grand Avenue and --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: 605 Grand Avenue is my house, and I was parked on the side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We'll get into that.  Nevertheless, that general location, Grand Avenue, Bon Air, Eagle Road, right in that vicinity, is that where the accident occurred?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Eagle is not even near that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  I'm going by the police report.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.  I'm just saying --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't we cut to the chase.  Where did -- where do you think it happened?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Bon Air and Grand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So May 24th, 2018, Bon Air and Grand Avenue is where the accident occurred?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to be asking you some questions about that accident today, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to give you instructions before we begin. These instructions were probably given to you by your attorney, but I want to make sure on the record that you hear them from me, you understand them, and then we'll move forward, okay?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  First of all, number one, don't answer any questions you don't understand, all right?  It's my job to formulate a question that you understand --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- not your attorney, not Ms. Brietman, not the court reporter, that only you understand.  So if you don't understand my question, just say, "Mike, I don't understand.  Could you please rephrase it," and I'll do so, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Another instruction:  You need to wait until I'm finished answering (sic) my question before you begin to answer.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The reason for that is because everything that's being said on the record is being taken down by the court reporter --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Right, each time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- to your right.  So we cannot speak over one another --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- as we would do normally, say, over a cup of coffee or a beer at a bar, okay?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I'll have to work on that.  That's --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's fine.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: -- gonna be tough for me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your attorney or myself or even the court reporter may remind you from time to time, but it's really -- we're not trying to be rude.  It's really important that you try to stick to that.  Just wait 'til I'm done.  I know you're gonna anticipate what I'm saying --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- but you need to wait, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All your answers need to be verbal.  You're doing fine so far.  You can move your hands, shake your head, shrug your shoulders, do whatever you want, but you have to accompany that with a word.  Do you understand?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Try to avoid things like "uh-uh," "uh-huh," "nah," "yeah."  We know what you mean, but sometimes that doesn't get transcribed well on the -- on the record, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Don't guess at anything, okay?  It's perfectly fine if you don't recall.  This, you know, happened what? almost like a year and -- and several months ago, so if -- if certain things don't come to mind, that's perfectly okay.  I may ask some -- a follow-up question to jog your memory, but if you still don't remember, don't outright guess. But the difference between an outright guess and knowing something but not every detail is this: If I asked you what you had for dinner last year on August 15th, even though you have pizza four times a week, you probably don't know exactly what you had that last year on this particular date, correct?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Possibly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  Maybe you did.  Maybe it was an anniversary or something.  But normally, people don't remember what they had for dinner a year ago.  That's an outright guess usually. But if I asked you something like, "How did you get here today?" you might not know every turn, every road, every street, but you probably can give me a good idea how you got here, correct?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  That's the difference between an outright guess and maybe not every detail, but you know the gist of what I'm asking, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Uh-uh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You feel comfortable with that?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You can take a break if you'd like.  I just ask that if a question is pending, that you wait -- that you -- that you answer the question before you take that break, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yeah.  I don't think we need a break.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fine.  But maybe you'll get a phone call or you need to --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I don't have a phone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Well, in any event, you are not being held hostage here today.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay?  So if you need to take a bathroom break, whatever you need to do, stretch your legs, whatever --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: We're good.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- we can take a break.  I don't expect this to be very long, okay?  I don't really have many questions for you.  Keep this in mind:  Number one, have you ever had your deposition taken before?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So this is all new to you, okay? Right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yeah.  It's a little scary, intimidating.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Don't be.  Just a conversation between me and you, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just asking you about the accident.  I'm gonna ask some background stuff about -- about your life, not many, but it's really just a conversation between me and you.  The only difference is that we're in a -- you know, we have a court reporter here.  We're in a conference room.  But it really is just a conversation, me asking you questions about this accident.  And then you're done, and you go on with your life, all right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there any reason that you can think of that would give you difficulty in understanding me today and providing truthful and accurate answers?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The oath that you took today, do you understand that that --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hold on.  Hold on.  I know you know where I'm going. The oath that you took today, you understand that's -- that's the kind of oath you -- well, it is the oath that you would take in a court of law, in front of judge and/or jury, right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that requires you to tell the truth under penalty of perjury.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Don't feel intimidated by it.  I tell that to everybody.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you on any medications today?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Have you reviewed any -- any documents or -- or things in preparation for this deposition?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you ready to start?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just give me your full name for the record, please.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Harry H. Orner.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what's your date of birth?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: And your current address?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: 15 West Eagle Road, Havertown, PA 19083.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you lived there?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Since first grade.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who do you live there with, if anyone?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Well, I lived there with my parents, but they passed away.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You live there alone now?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Currently, I'm the only one living in that residence.  It's an apartment.  It's over top of the garden center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the answer is yes, you live alone, right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: With two cats.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, with two -- no human beings?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you plan on moving any time soon?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where do you plan on moving to and when?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: 605 Grand Avenue, which was a rental property at the time of the accident, and it will be in the spring of next year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  You say "Grand Avenue."  Where's -- where's that located?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Bon Air and Grand, where the accident happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would that be Havertown Township?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Havertown, PA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Havertown, PA or Haverford, PA?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Havertown.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Havertown.  I'm not familiar with this --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Delaware County.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So nearby, right?  You're not going to Europe or anything like that?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Are you employed?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been employed?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Last time I was employed was 2014.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I was a -- I worked at the garden center, watering plants.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you have that job?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Off and on, 20 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm gonna ask you a question I ask every witness, okay?  And your attorney is probably gonna ask my client this.  Have you ever been convicted of a crime of falsehood or dishonesty within the last four -- ten years?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Such things as -- I'll give examples -- forgery, perjury, fraud.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's just jump right to the day of the accident, okay?  We agree that it's May 24th, 2018?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I guess.  That's -- would sound right, May 24th.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you disagree with it?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just going by the police report.  I'm not trying to trick you.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.  It's fine, if that's what it says.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What time of day did this happen?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Around 5:00 o'clock p.m.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I understand that the location of this accident was outside of your residence; is that right?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I was at my house, doing spring cleanup.  I was there all day, filling trash cans and cutting firewood. And I was basically there for about seven hours.  And I was preparing to go up the street --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Listen to what he asked you.
speaker: MS. KRENICKY

text: Oh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm gonna break it down for you, okay?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's okay.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I was running -- running off there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  It's okay.  I know you want to get your story out.  That's fine.  But I'm -- I'm gonna break it down for you, and we'll just do it in pieces, okay?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Pieces.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: What was the question?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  You answered it.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mentioned that the location of the -- the impact, that was on Grand Avenue?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No.  It was -- it was on Bon Air.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It was on Bon Air, okay.  And Bon Air, is that a -- a two-lane street, a one-way street?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I would say it's a three-lane street, one side for parking, and the other side is for going up and back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: It was parked on my normal parking spot on Bon Air, by the bushes.  You know, I think there's a photograph somewhere of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He's talking about this.
speaker: MS. KRENICKY

text: Yeah.  Can I use this?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. KRENICKY

text: That's where I was parked at this day of the accident.  That's pretty much the same spot.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We'll have this marked as Orner-1.  I do have a copy of this in black and white, but I'll hand you the -- the color copy.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: (Exhibit Orner-1 marked for identification.)
Yeah, that's me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Let me ask you some questions.  The location of your -- your -- is that your truck?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The location of your truck in -- in Orner-1, is that where it was, say, five minutes before the impact occurred?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Within a foot or two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the -- roughly the same area, correct?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I park there every time I -- every time I come, I -- I park there unless there's a car there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the lane of travel directly next to your truck, is that to come down the street toward the left of the photograph?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And the lane next to that, which I'll say what would be to the right of -- of the lane we just spoke about, going up to the right top of the photograph, is -- is -- is that direction -- the direction for that lane of travel?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just to cut to the chase:  My understanding is that my client's vehicle was traveling in the lane directly next to your vehicle, heading down toward the left of the photograph, correct?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.  She came down here and stopped at the stop sign.

text: Right.  And I was gonna get to that.  At this intersection, I'll call it, there's a stop sign?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yes.

text: All right.  And that -- that truck, is that a Ford F-150?

text: Correct.

text: And according to the police report, it's -- the year is 1985?

text: Correct.

text: Google.

text: -- did you print it out from Google?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Today is the first day I saw that photograph.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  It appears from this photograph that there might be some -- and I can't tell if it's a bush in the background or in your vehicle, but --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Let me see.

text: No.

text: Okay.

text: Let's -- let's go back to the day of the accident. Was there debris, material, anything like that in the back of your vehicle, in the -- in the bed of the truck?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I'm not sure.  I was thinking about that last night, and I'm really not sure whether there were trash cans in the back of the truck or not, because I'd been cleaning all day and I'd been filling tash cans out.  And I had a bunch of trash cans over here. And usually, what I do is I put them in the back of the truck, and then I take them to the garden center because we have a dumpster there.  So I don't know if I had any in there.  I don't -- I could have put some in there during the day.  I'm not sure.  I'm not a hundred percent sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's fine.  Again, like I said, if you don't remember --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I'm not -- yeah.  I'm not sure.  I know there was three over here, but there could have been two in the back.  Can't -- I can't --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say "back," you mean the back of your truck, the bed of the truck?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Could have been in the back of the truck, which may have obstructed my view.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  That's fine.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I just -- I'm not a hundred percent sure of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's fine, okay?  Let's go back to the day of the accident, okay?  Did you have a side-view mirror on each side of your vehicle, your side and the passenger side?

text: Yeah, there's -- there's side-view mirrors on both sides, and then there's the main mirror, which -- which would, you know, see through this grate.

text: All right.  So the grate --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: There's a -- there's a big, metal, black grate.

text: The grate protects -- the grate is the rear of the cab, which protects --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: The grate's addition.  It's a metal diamond plate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  But I'm just trying to describe for the record, because I know what it is --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- you know what it is, but so when we go back and read it five months from now --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- we know what it is.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Okay.

text: All right.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Yeah.  It protects the passenger against debris.

text: Yes.

text: All right.

text: That's my m.o. with --

text: No.  I -- my mirrors are fine.

text: Okay.  At any rate, why don't you tell me what you recall about how the accident occurred.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Well, I got in the truck, and I was gonna back up a little bit so I could get closer to my trash cans.  And I was moving probably about two to three miles an hour.  And I backed up approximately one car length, and that's when the truck stopped moving.

text: Why?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Well, I got out and I -- I saw Carla.

text: Did you -- did you -- did you know at that point when it stopped moving that you had come in contact with another vehicle?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I never felt contact with another vehicle.  I was backing up very slowly, and I felt resistance, I would say.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you put the -- your --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: It was no -- there was no impact on -- on my part.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You -- when you put your vehicle in reverse --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I put it in park at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  Look, let me finish.

text: He's a couple steps earlier.

text: I'm going back a little earlier, before the impact.

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Car is parked.  You get in.  Did I say "car"? Truck is parked.  You get in.  You intend to back up.  You put it in reverse, correct?

text: Well, I looked first to see if I --

text: Yeah.

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So the answer is yes, you did?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct, but very little pressure, because I was backing up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Let's go back again to when you first got in your truck before the impact.  You said you looked behind you?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you look behind you?  What did you do?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Well, as I was getting in the truck, I did a visual look to see what was going on.  And, you know, I could see -- I could see -- see, this is open in here.  I could see -- I could basically see what's going on. I jumped in the truck.  I started it, and then I paused for a little bit to let it warm up just a hair.  And then I turned around and looked, and it looked clear.

text: Correct.

text: Meaning she would have --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Drove by me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Correct.

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No, never saw it.

text: I did look back.

text: All right.  You look back -- you looked at your general surroundings before you got in your truck, correct?

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: So your answer is yes, you went and looked?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I went and looked.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At that point, what did you see when you looked?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I saw my truck alongside of her car, alongside of it, not behind it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say "your truck," tell me, in your words, what part of your truck was in contact with her vehicle.

text: My bumper was in contact with her rear taillight maybe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What part of your bumper, driver's side, middle, or passenger side bumper of your vehicle?

text: The passenger side bumper was -- was making contact with her rear panel.

text: Rear panel.  What side of her vehicle?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Passenger side on her car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After you saw that, what did you do?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Well, I wasn't sure how -- how, you know, much damage there may have been, so I decided to move my truck back into my parking spot.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Take it a step back.  When -- before you did that, and you're taking the first visual of the contact of -- between your vehicle and my client's vehicle, what damage, if any, did you see?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No damage.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: None at all?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: No damage.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So then you -- I think you said you -- you went around and got back in your vehicle?

text: And did you do that?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I did that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what happened, if anything, when you did that?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: The bumper came off of her vehicle.

text: All right.  We're gonna have marked collectively -- I'll have these marked collectively as Orner-2.  But before I do that, I'm gonna ask you this:  After you moved your vehicle back to the parking spot and you said that the bumper of her vehicle came off, did -- at any point after that, did you go outside of your vehicle and take a look at my client's vehicle?

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.  Sounds right.

text: That's all I have for you for these -- these photographs.  All right. Other than the -- the -- I'll say conversation or -- or words exchanged that you've already spoke about between yourself and my client, was anything else said between you and my client at any point at the accident scene?

text: Yeah, there was things said.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, she said that I hit her vehicle.  She said that she tried to beep and use the horn, I guess, to warn me.  I told her that I didn't hear the horn.  I told her I never saw her and that I was sorry that I backed into her.

text: You talked about a horn.  Are you saying today you never heard a horn --
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: Never heard a horn --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- beep?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: -- nope.  She said she had hit the horn though.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I called when I got home.  And they asked me a bunch of stuff and said that they would --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall -- okay.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: -- write an accident --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Probably.

text: I don't know.

At line 51, your answer to a question was: "I didn't see her.  I started -- I backed out of the spot, and she said she beeped the horn.  Umm. "QUESTION:  Uh-huh. "ANSWER:  I heard a horn.  I looked again and I still couldn't see her, because I'm in a truck and she's in this little car." After we -- after me having read that to you, what I'm gonna purport is a statement provided by your attorney in your responses to my discovery request, do you still maintain today that you never heard a horn?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I didn't hear a horn.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So that's -- that sentence I just read of your recorded statement, that's incorrect?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: That's -- that's got to be a -- a misstatement.  I never heard a horn.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  On page 14 of this -- of the recorded statement that we're -- we're speaking about, at line -- at line 565, your answer to a question about the accident was: "She chose -- she chose -- she -- she -- she saw me backing up, and she -- and she chose to use the horn. "QUESTION:  So she did honk the horn? "ANSWER:  She honked the horn, correct. "QUESTION:  And you did hear it? "ANSWER:  I heard a horn, and I looked around, and I still didn't see her."
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I don't --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hold on. "QUESTION:  Okay. "ANSWER:  I looked.  I looked both ways and I didn't see anything.  I'm like, What -- what is this horn thing going on?" All right.  So now we've talked about two instances where you discuss a horn, the second one at length, in this recorded statement.  And so as you sit here today, you're still saying you didn't hear a horn?
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I don't remember hearing a horn.  I remember her telling me she honked the horn.  That's why the horn thing is in -- in my head, because she said she was honking the horn.  I don't remember hearing the horn.  Usually, if I hear a horn, I hit the brakes immediately.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But would you agree with me that these questions and answers I just read to you, they -- the questions and answers I just read to you reflect that you did hear a horn that day?  I mean just from what I read.

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: I disagree.

speaker: MR. GALLAGHER

text: This was --

text: All right.

Maybe I misspoke to the Progressive guy about the horn, but I don't remember hearing a horn and I don't remember seeing her. I didn't see her drive by me.  I never saw her at the -- at the intersection.  The only -- the first time I knew she was there is when the truck stopped.
